improvement.suggestion: Hello everyone, I am Vick Shant. Today we will be learning about OOP (Object-Oriented Programming), a paradigm that structures programs around objects rather than functions and logic. We'll explore its core concepts using a simple coffee machine example.

sentences.text: So think of the coffee machine as a class. It's like a blueprint. It defines the functions of a coffee machine like making a coffee, making a cappuccino, a latte, etc. Now when you buy a real coffee machine it's like an object right it is by it and placed on a table like an object. Now let's come to the OOPs part of it. So the OOPs has four different pillars.

The first one is encapsulation. Now what is the capsule? It's the capsule right? What is the capsule? It has a medicine inside and it's hidden by the outer capsule. Now in terms of the coffee machine, a coffee machine has some internal wiring, it has a heating element, it has a coffee grinder, it's all hidden under the outer casing. Now this is encapsulation like bundling of data and hiding under the casing. Now moving on to the next one, it is abstraction.

improvement.reason: The definition of encapsulation could be more precise in a programming context, linking it to data and methods.
improvement.suggestion: The first one is encapsulation. Just like a medicine capsule hides its contents, a coffee machine's internal wiring, heating element, and grinder are hidden under its outer casing. In programming, encapsulation means bundling data (attributes) and the methods (functions) that operate on that data within a single unit, and restricting direct access to some of the object's internal details.

improvement.suggestion: Now it may seem like a big term, but it really isn't. Suppose I want an espresso. How do I tell the machine? I just press a button for 'espresso', and it gives me one. I don't care about the internal steps to make an espresso; that's handled by the machine. So, the machine is abstracting the complex function of making an espresso and simply giving me a button. That is abstraction.

improvement.reason: Contains verbal stumbles, grammatical errors ('addigates'), and a critical mispronunciation of 'polymorphism' as 'spawning morphism'.
improvement.suggestion: Moving on to the next one, it's inheritance. Inheritance is really simple, like inheriting your father's property. In terms of a coffee machine, suppose you have a smaller coffee machine, and then your budget increases, and you buy a premium one. The smaller one might only make espresso and heat water. The premium one, however, makes cappuccino, makes a latte, and definitely makes an espresso and heats water. So, it is inheriting the properties of the base model and also adding its own unique properties. Think of cars: a base version and a higher-end model. The higher-end model has all the features of the base one, plus some extra features. Now, moving on to the last one: polymorphism.
